history: The Acropolis of Athens, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, has been a sacred site since Neolithic times. It became a citadel in the Mycenaean period. The most iconic buildings, including the Parthenon, were constructed during the Golden Age of Athens under Pericles. Over the centuries, it has been occupied by various civilizations and was heavily damaged by Venetians in the 17th century. In the 19th century, restoration efforts began and continue to this day.
Ecological Relevance: The Acropolis serves as a symbol of ancient Greek civilization, architectural achievement, and democracy. It also attracts millions of tourists annually, contributing significantly to the economy.

timeline.Details: Construction of the Parthenon on the Acropolis during the Golden Age of Athens.
The Persians sack and burn the Acropolis during the Greco-Persian Wars.
The Acropolis is converted into a Christian church dedicated to the Virgin Mary.
The Parthenon is damaged during the Venetian siege of Athens.
Extensive restoration and excavation work begins on the Acropolis, including by archaeologist Heinrich Schliemann.
The Acropolis is designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The New Acropolis Museum is opened to the public, showcasing artifacts from the site.
The Acropolis temporarily closes to visitors due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
